Planc. 10, 26; cf.: in meā salute custodiendā,id. ib. 1, 1: me non solum amicorum fidelitas, sed etiam universae civitatis oculi custodiunt,id. Phil. 12, 9, 22: ut haec insula ab eā (Cerere) ... incoli custodirique videatur,Cic. Verr. 2, 4, 49, § 107: urbes,Quint. 7, 10, 13: maritimam oram viginti navibus longis,Liv. 36, 2, 11 (cf. tueri, id. 36, 2, 7): officinam diligentiā,Plin. 12, 14, 32, § 59: castra nocte, ne quis elabi posset,Liv. 9, 42, 6: amictum,Quint. 5, 14, 31: poma in melle,to lay up, preserve,Col. 12, 45, 3: paries, qui laevum marinae Veneris latus Custodit,Hor. C. 3, 26, 6: tua,id. S. 2, 3, 151: hic stilus ... me veluti custodiet ensis,id. ib. 2, 1, 40.—Esp.: se, to be on the watch: quanto se opere custodiant bestiae,Cic. N. D. 2, 49, 126: fac ut diligentissime te ipsum custodias,id. Att. 14, 17, A, 8.—
With ab: Gortynii templum magnā curā custodiunt non tam a ceteris quam ab Hannibale,Nep. Hann. 9, 4: poma ab insomni dracone,Ov. M. 9, 190: cutem a vitiis,Plin. 28, 8, 25, § 89.—

With immaterial objects (freq. in postAug. prose), to keep, preserve, regard, take heed, observe, maintain: id quod tradatur posse percipere animo et memoriā custodire,Cic. de Or. 1, 28, 127: dicta litteris,id. ib. 2, 2, 7; cf.: ex his (arboribus) quas memoria hominum custodit,Plin. 16, 44, 85, § 234: illa quae scriptis reposuimus, velut custodire desinimus,Quint. 11, 2, 9; opp. mutare,id. 12, 8, 6: modum ubique,id. 4, 2, 35: regulam loquendi,id. 1, 7, 1: praecepta,Col. 1, 8, 15: eam rationem,id. 4, 29, 11: ordinem,id. 12, 4, 1: quae custodienda in olearam curā ... praecipiemus,Plin. 17, 18, 29, § 125: morem,id. 14, 12, 14, § 88: religiose quod juraveris,id. Pan. 65, 2 et saep.—
With ab: teneriores annos ab injuriā sanctitas docentis custodiat,Quint. 2, 2, 3.—

With ut or ne: in aliis quoque propinquitatibus custodiendum est, ut inviti judicemur dixisse,Quint. 11, 1, 66: quo in genere id est praecipue custodiendum, ne, etc.,id. 8, 3, 73; 8, 5, 7; Col. 4, 24, 11: ut custoditum sit ne umquam veniret, etc.,Suet. Tib. 7.—
With the access. idea of hindering free motion, in a good or bad sense.

In gen., to hold something back, to preserve, keep: multorum te oculi et aures non sentientem ... speculabuntur atque custodient,Cic. Cat. 1, 2, 6: aliquem, ne quid auferat,to watch, observe,id. Div. in Caecil. 16, 51: ejus (sc. epistulae) custodiendae et proferendae arbitrium tuum,Cic. Att. 15, 13, 1: librum,id. Fam. 6, 5, 1: codicillos,Suet. Tib. 51: prodit se quamlibet custodiatur simulatio,Quint. 12, 1, 29.—

Esp., to hold in custody, hold captive: noctu nervo vinctus custodibitur,Plaut. Capt. 3, 5, 71; Cic. Fragm. ap. Quint. 9, 3, 50: ducem praedonum,Cic. Verr. 2, 5, 27, § 68: obsides,Caes. B. G. 6, 4: Domitium,id. B. C. 1, 20: bovem,Verg. A. 8, 218 et saep.—Hence, * cu-stōdītē, adv. (acc. to I.), cautiously, carefully: ut parce custoditeque ludebat!Plin. Ep. 5, 16, 3.
In gen., guardianship, care: custoditio est opera ad custodiendum quid sumpta, Paul. ex Fest. p. 61, 15.—
Transf., a keeping, observance: legum,Vulg. Sap. 6, 19.
a guard, watch, preserver, keeper, overseer, protector, defender, attendant, etc., protectress, etc., in a friendly or hostile sense (freq. and class.).
In gen.
Of living beings.

In gen.: antiqua erilis fida custos corporis, Enn. Med. ap. Non. p. 39, 2 (Trag. Rel. v. 289 Vahl.); cf. in masc.: corporis,a body-guard,Liv. 24, 7, 4; so plur., Nep. Dat. 9, 3; Suet. Calig. 55 al.: Commium cum equitatu custodis loco relinquit,Caes. B. G. 6, 6 fin.: cum vigillis custodibusque nostris colloqui,id. B. C. 1, 22 init.: portae,Cic. Cat. 2, 12, 27: fani,Cic. Verr. 2, 4, 43, § 94. custos defensorque provinciae, id. ib. 2, 5, 6, § 12: pontis,Nep. Milt. 3, 1: patrimonii,Quint. 4, 2, 73: hortorum,Suet. Calig. 59: gregis,Verg. E. 10, 36: pecuniae regiae,Curt. 5, 1, 20: ipse pecuniae quam regni melior custos, Liv 44, 26, 12: rei  publicae custos senatus, Cic. Sest. 65, 137: templorum,id. Dom. 55, 141: custos ac vindex cupiditatum,id. Agr. 2, 9, 24: salutis suae,Quint. 5, 11, 8; Curt. 3, 6, 1; Tac. A. 3, 14 et saep.: his discipulis privos custodes dabo,Plaut. Ps. 3, 2, 76; so of teachers of youth, id. ib. 4, 3, 19; Ter. Phorm. 2, 1, 57; Hor. S. 1, 4, 118; id. A. P. 161; 239: virtutis (ego) verae custos rigidusque satelles,id. Ep. 1, 1, 17.—Freq. of the gods, etc.: dei custodes et conservatores hujus urbis,Cic. Sest. 24, 53; cf.: custodi Jovi,Suet. Dom. 5: montium custos Diana,Hor. C. 3, 22, 1: rerum Caesar,id. ib. 4, 15, 17: multae tibi tum officient res, Custodes, etc., i. e. attendants of women, eunuchs, etc., id. S. 1, 2, 98 Heind.—Of dogs, Verg. G. 3, 406; Col. 7, 12; so of Cerberus,Verg. A. 6, 424 al., and of the constellation Bootes, *)arktofu/lac, Vitr. 9, 4, 1: armorum, the officer in charge of the arms in an army or fleet, Dig. 49, 16, 14, § 1; Inscr. Orell. 3630 al.—
In civil affairs, t. t., a man who took charge of the vessel into which voting tablets were put (in order to prevent false suffrages), Varr. R. R. 3, 5, 18; Cic. Agr. 2, 9, 22; id. Red. Sen. 7, 17.—
Of inanimate subjects.

Of abstract subjects: natura Ipsaque corporis est custos et causa salutis,Lucr. 3, 324: haec custos dignitatis (fortitudo),Cic. Tusc. 2, 14, 33: sapientia custos et procuratrix totius hominis,id. Fin. 4, 7, 17; id. Off. 2, 7, 23: leges diligentissimae pudoris custodes,Quint. 8, 5, 19 al.—

Of receptacles, safes, e. g. of a quiver: eburnea Telorum custos,Ov. M. 8, 320; of an incense-box: turis,id. ib. 13, 703; and in husbandry, the stump of an amputated vine-branch, i. q. resex, pollex, praesidiarius or subsidiarius palmes, Col. 4, 21, 3.—
In a hostile sense.

In gen., a watch, spy: Dumnorigi custodes ponit, ut, quae agat, quibuscum loquatur, scire possit,Caes. B. G. 1, 20 fin.: custodem, inquit, Tullio me apponite. Quid, mihi quam multis custodibus opus erit, etc.,Cic. Div. in Caecil. 16, 51; Cic. Verr. 2, 5, 25, § 63; Caes. B. G. 1, 20 fin.: num nam hic relictu's custos, Nequis, etc.,Ter. Eun. 2, 2, 55; cf. v. 59; Curt. 5, 11, 2; Suet. Tib. 12 al.—

Esp., a jailer, keeper: carceris,Plaut. Mil. 2, 2, 57; Nep. Eum. 11, 1; id. Alcib. 4, 4: quem ex Mauritania rex proditionis insimulatum cum custodibus miserat,Sall. H. 2, 25 Dietsch: te sub custode tenebo,Hor. Ep. 1, 16, 77; Tac. A. 2, 68; 3, 28; 4, 60 al.
front_matter: custos, ōdis, comm.root sku-, to cover, hide, etc.; cf. scutum, keu/qw, Germ. Haut, Haus, Corss. Ausspr. I. p. 353,

entries: a small river in Germania, now prob. the Waag, Tac. A. 2, 63 fin.
the skin, Juv. 11, 203; Pers. 4, 18; on the long ī, v. Prisc. p. 612 P.

an ancient city in the Sabine land, on a lake called Lacus Cutiliae, now Lago di Contigliano, Varr. ap. Plin. 3, 12, 17, § 109; Paul. ex Fest. 51, 8.—Also in plur.: Cŭtĭlĭae, ārum, Liv. 26, 11, 10; Suet. Vesp. 24; Cels. 5, 6; Sen. Q. N. 3, 25, 6; Paul. ex Fest. p. 51, 8 Müll.—Hence, Cŭtĭlĭensis, e, adj.: Lacus,Varr. L. L. 5, § 71 Müll.; Macr. S. 1, 7, 28 sq.; and Cŭtĭlĭus, a, um, adj., of Cutilia: Cutiliae aquae,Plin. 2, 95, 96, § 209; 31, 2, 6, § 10; Cael. Aur. Tard. 3, 2, 45.—Also called Cŭ-tĭlĭae, ārum, f., Cels. 4, 5, 26.
a city of the Vestini, Liv. 8, 29, 13.
a small insect, milleped, Marc. Emp. 8.
the skin.

Prov.: curare cutem, to take care of one's skin, i. e. to make much of one's self, Hor. Ep. 1, 2, 29; 1, 4, 15 (for which pelliculam curare, id. S. 2, 5, 38): cogere aliquem intra suam cutem,Sen. Ep. 9, 13: cute perditus,sick in one's body,Pers. 1, 23: ego te intus et in cute novi,I know you thoroughly,id. 3, 30.—
Transf.
Hide, leather: calceus est sartā terque quaterque cute,Mart. 1, 103, 6.—

A soft coating, covering of any thing; the skin, rind, surface (several times in the Nat. Hist. of Pliny): casiae,Plin. 12, 19, 43, § 95: nucleorum,id. 15, 10, 9, § 36: uvarum,id. 15,   28, 34, § 112: lauri,id. 27, 10, 60, § 84: summa terrae,id. 20, 19, 79, § 207.—
Trop., the external appearance, surface, outside: tenerā quādam elocutionis cute,Quint. 5, 12, 18: imaginem virtutis effingere et solam ut sic dixerim cutem,id. 10, 2, 15; Gell. 18, 4, 2.
front_matter: cŭtis, is (acc. cutem, App. Mag. p. 306, 14), f. kindr. with ku/tos; Sanscr. gudh; Germ. Haut,
cuturnĭumvas, quo in sacrificiis vinum fundebatur, Paul. ex Fest. p. 51, 1 Müll.

entries: the beanstone, a precious stone, Plin. 37, 11, 73, § 188.
a plant, called also colocasia, Egyptian bean, Plin. 21, 15, 51, § 87.

a fountain near Syracuse, Plin. 3, 8, 14, § 89; Ov. F. 4, 469; id. P. 2, 10, 26.—In fable, a nymph changed into this fountain for her grief at the loss of Proserpine, Ov. M. 5, 409 sq.; Sil. 14, 515; Claud. Rapt. Pros. 3, 245.

front_matter: Cȳănĕae, ārum, f., v. cyaneus, II.

entries: a nymph, daughter of Maeander, mother of Caunus and of Byblis, Ov. M. 9, 452.
Dark-blue, sea-blue: cyaneo colore avis,Plin. 10, 32, 47, § 89: stagna,Prud. Psych. 858.—
Cȳănĕae, ārum, f., = *kua/neai, the two small rocky islands at the entrance of the Pontus Euxinus, called also Symplegades, q. v., Ov. Tr. 1, 10, 34; Mel. 2, 7, 3: errantes,Val. Fl. 4, 561.—Hence,
Cȳă-nĕus, a, um, adj., of or belonging to the Cyaneae: cautes,Luc. 2, 716: montes,Val. Fl. 2, 381: rupes,id. 4, 637: ruinae,Mart. 7, 19, 3: insulae,Mel. 2, 7, 3; Plin. 4, 13, 27, § 92 al.—
Transf., like the Cyaneae: nates,Mart. 11, 99, 6.
The blue corn-flower, blue-bottle: Centaurea cyanus, Linn.; Plin. 21, 8, 24, § 48; 21, 11, 39, § 68.—
A precious stone, a species of lapis lazuli, Plin. 37, 9, 38, § 119.
to fill a cyathus, Plaut. Men. 2, 2, 29; Macr. de Diff. 41, 8; Auct. de Verb. 8, § 14 Jan.
a small ladle for transferring the wine from the mixing-bowl (crater) to the drinking-cup (cf. Becker, Gall. 3, p. 221).
Prop., Varr. L. L. 5, § 124 Müll.; Plaut. Stich. 5, 4, 24; id. Ps. 4, 2, 2; Hor. S. 1, 6, 117; Juv. 9, 47; Suet. Caes. 49 al.—

As a measure, both dry and liquid (particularly for wine), the twelfth part of a sextarius, Hor. C. 3, 8, 13; 3, 19, 12; Plin. 14, 9, 11, § 85; or ten Greek drachmae, Plin. 21, 34, 109, § 185; cf. Rhemn. Fann. Pond. 80.
pertaining to a kind of merchantship: navis maxima,Cic. Verr. 2, 5, 17, § 44.—Absol.: cybaea, ae, f., a transport or merchant-ship, Cic. Verr. 2, 4, 8, § 17.
front_matter: cybaeus, a, um, adj.ku/ph, kubh/, cupa,

entries: A goddess, originally Phrygian, later worshipped in Rome also as Ops or Mater Magna, whose priests were called Galli.
Form Cybele, Cat. 63, 8; Verg. A. 11, 768; Mart. 1, 71, 10.—
Form Cybela, Tert. adv. Nat. 1, 10.—
Hence,

Cybĕ-lēĭus, a, um, adj., pertaining to Cybele: Attis,Ov. M. 10, 104; v. Attis: mater, i. q. Cybele, id. A. A. 1, 507; so also dea,id. F. 4, 191: frena,i. e. of the lions in the chariot of Cybele,id. M. 10, 704: limina,i. e. of her temple,Stat. S. 1, 2, 176.—
Cybĕlista, ae, m., = *kubelisth/s, a priest of Cybele, Verg. Copa, 25 Sillig ex conj. (al. Calybita). —
A mountain in Phrygia.
Form Cybele, Ov. F. 4, 249; 4, 363.—
Form Cybebe, Cat. 63, 9; 63, 84.—Also called Cybĕ-lus, i, m., Verg. A. 3, 111 Rib. (al. Cybelae).
front_matter: Cybĕlē or Cybēbē, ēs, and Cybĕ-lă, ae, f., = *kube/lh and *kubh/bh.

entries: a dealer in salt fish, Arn. 2, p. 70 dub.
the night hawk: nocturnus accipiter cybindis vocatur,Plin. 10, 8, 10, § 24.
a dealer in salt fish; nickname of the thirteenth Ptolemy, and later of the emperor Vespasian, Suét. Vesp. 19.
a town of Cappadocia,Cic. Fam. 15, 2, 2 and 4; id. Att. 5, 18, 1 al.
A tunny-fish, Varr. L. L. 5, § 77 Müll.; Mart. 11, 27, 3; cf. Paul. ex Fest. p. 52, 15 Müll.—
Meton., a dish made of pieces of the tunny-fish salted and chopped, Plin. 9, 15, 18, § 48; 32, 11, 53, § 151; Mart. 5, 79, 3.
a drink made of barley-grits, grated goats'-cheese, and wine, Arn. 5, p. 174 sq.
a bird migrating with quails, perh. the ortolan, Plin. 10, 23, 33, §§ 66 and 68.
clothed with a cyclas, Suet. Calig. 52.
the plant sowbread: Cyclamen Europaeum, Linn.; of several kinds,Plin. 25, 9, 67, § 114 sq.
front_matter: cyclămīnŏs, i, f. (-on, i, n., Plin. 21, 9, 27, § 51; 21, 11, 38, § 64), = kukla/mi=nos and kukla/minon,

entries: Liddell and Scott in h. v. l.),a state-robe of women, with a border running round it,Prop. 4 (5), 7, 40.Juv. 6, 259; Vop. Sat. 9; Lampr. Alex. Sev. 41, 1; Serv. ad Verg. A. 1, 649 al.—

Cȳclădes, um, f., = *kukla/des, the Cyclades, islands lying in a circle round Delos, in the Aegean Sea, off the coast of the Peloponnesus, Mel. 2, 7, 11; Plin. 4, 12, 22, § 65 sq.; Caes. B. C. 3, 3; Nep. Milt. 2, 5; Liv. 34, 26, 11; Verg. A. 3, 127; Ov. Tr. 1, 11, 8; id. M. 2, 264; Stat. Th. 5, 183.—Sing., Vitr. 7, 7, 3; Juv. 6, 563; Sil. 4, 347; Sen. Herc. Oet. 804.
front_matter: cȳclas, ădis, f., = kukla/s (circular; hence as in Greek; cf.

entries: Cyclicus scriptor, a cyclic poet, one of the epic poets who treated in regular order the cycle of myths from the beginning of the world to the time of Telemachus, Hor. A. P. 136: cyclica carmina,cyclic poems,Isid. Orig. 6, 17, 4; cf. Liddell and Scott, s. v. kukliko/s, II.—
Forming a complete cycle, encyclopaedic: disciplinae,Mart. Cap. 9, § 998.
front_matter: cyclĭcus, a, um, adj., = kukliko/s, prop. circular; hence,

entries: moved in a circle, circular: cyma,Mart. Cap. 8, p. 275 (written as Greek by Kopp, § 814).

a Cyclops; in plur.: Cyclopes, um,the Cyclopes, a fabulous race of giants on the coast of Sicily; said to have each but one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead; to them were ascribed the walls called Cyclopean; plur.,Cic. Div. 2, 19, 43; Plin. 7, 56, 57, §§ 195-198; Verg. A. 6, 630; 8, 424; Hor. C. 1, 4, 7; Ov. M. 3, 305 et saep.; sing. kat) e)coxh/n, the Cyclops Polyphemus, Verg. A. 3, 617; Hor. A. P. 145; Ov. M. 13, 744 sq.; 14, 174 sq.; Cic. Verr. 2, 5, 56, § 146 et saep.: Cyclopa saltare,to imitate Polyphemus by pantomime,Hor. S. 1, 5, 63; so, moveri,id. Ep. 2, 2, 125 Orell.— Hence,
Adj.

Cȳclōpēus, a, um, = *kuklw/peios, Cyclopean, of the Cyclopes; only plur as subst.: Cȳclōpēa, ōrum, n., the myth of the Cyclopes as represented in a pantomime: ludere, Treb. Poll. Gall. 8, 3; Vop. Carin. 19, 3.—
Cȳclōpĭus, a, um, adj., of or pertaining to the Cyclopes: saxa, in Sicily,Verg. A. 1, 201: at Mycenae,Sen. Herc. Fur. 997: regna,Sil. 14, 33.
front_matter: Cȳclops, ōpis (acc. -ōpem or -ōpa), m., = *ku/klwy (a round eye),

entries: a circle.
Lit.: cycli axium,Isid. Orig. 3, 36.—
Transf.
Astron. t. t., a cycle, recurring period: paschalis,the Easter cycle of ninety-five years,Isid. Orig. 6, 17, 1: lunae,the lunar cycle of nineteen years,id. ib. 6, 17, 5.—
Med. t. t., a periodic change, a recurrence: resumptionis,Cael. Aur. Tard. 1, 1, 21: metasyncriticus,id. ib. 1, 1, 24; cf.: cyclo curare,Veg. Art. Vet. 5, 5, 3; 3, 6, 1.—
An instrument for branding, Veg. Vet. 2, 5, 3; 2, 6, 11.
a kind of eye-salve, Inscr. Orell. 4234.
adj., of or pertaining to the Boeotian Cycnus, the son of Hyrie: Tempe,in Boeotia,Ov. M. 7, 371.
Of or belonging to a swan, swan's-: tamquam cycnea vox et oratio,i. e. the last speech,Cic. de Or. 3, 2, 6: plumae,Ov. Tr. 4, 8, 1.—
Cȳcnēa (al.  Cygnaea) Specula, a hill near Brixia, now still Cigneo, Cat. 67, 32.

y,Hor. C. 4, 3, 20; Aus. Ep. 20, 8), i, m., = ku/knos, the swan; celebrated for its singing, esp. for its dying song; consecrated to Apollo,Cic. Tusc. 1, 30, 73; Plin. 10, 23, 32, § 63; Lucr. 4, 181; 4, 910; Verg. E. 7, 38; id. A. 1, 393; Ov. M. 5, 387; Hor. C. 4, 3, 20 et saep.; attached to the chariot of Venus,Ov. M. 10, 708; id. A. A. 3, 809.—
Prov.: quid contendat hirundo cycnis?Lucr. 3, 7; so also: certent cycnis ululae,Verg. E. 8, 55.—
Meton., for a poet: Dircaeus,i. e. Pindar,Hor. C. 4, 2, 25.
front_matter: cȳcnus (in MSS. and edd. freq. also cȳgnus;

entries: A king of the Ligurians, son of Sthenelus, related to Phaeton, who was changed to a swan and placed among the stars, Ov. M. 2, 367; Verg. A. 10, 189; cf. Hyg. Fab. 154; id. Astr. 3, 7. —
A son of Neptune and Calyce; he was father of Tenes, and was changed into a swan, Ov. M. 12, 72 sq., cf. Hyg. Fab. 157.‡ † cydărum, i, n., = ku/daros, a sort of ship, acc. to Gell. 10, 25, 5.
The mistress of Acontius, Ov. H. 20; 21; id. A. A. 1, 457.—
A Nereid, Verg. G. 4, 339; Hyg. Fab. praef.

a river in Cilicia, famed for its cold and tonic waters, now Kara - Su or Tersustschai, Mel. 1, 13, 1; Plin. 5, 27, 22, § 92; Cic. Phil. 2, 11, 26; Vitr. 8, 3, 6; Curt. 3, 4, 7 sq.; 3, 5, 1 sqq.; Tib. 1, 7, 13 al.
an ancient and celebrated town on the north coast of Crete, now Canea, Mel. 2, 7, 12; Plin. 4, 12, 20, § 59 Sillig N. cr.; Flor. 3, 7, 4.—
Hence,
Cydon, ōnis, m.
A Cydonian, Verg. A. 12, 858.—
A son of Phorcus, Verg. A. 10, 325.—In plur., Luc. 7, 229.—

Cydō-nĭus, a, um, adj., Cydonian: spicula, poet. for Cretan, Verg. E. 10, 59; cf. arcus,Hor. C. 4, 9, 17.—So esp. freq. Cydonia (and Latinized cotonia, cotonea) mala; also absol.: cydōnĭa (cŏtōnĭa, cŏtōnĕa), ōrum, n., a quince or quince-apple, Plin. 15, 11, 10, § 37; Col. 5, 10, 19; Macr. S. 7, 6; Varr. R. R. 1, 59; Col. 12, 47, 1; Prop. 3 (4), 13, 27.—Cydonia arbor, or absol.: cydōnĭus, ii, f., a quince-tree, Pall. Febr. 25, 21; 25, 20; id. Insit. 99 al.—cydōnĕum, i, n., quincejuice, quince-wine, Dig. 33, 6, 9.—
Cy-dōnēus, a, um, adj., Cydonian: juvencae,Ov. A. A. 1, 293: pharetrae, poet. for Cretan, id. M. 8, 22: sagittae,Stat. Th. 7, 339: harundo,Sil. 10, 261.—
Cydōnītes, ae, adj., Cydonian: vites,Col. 3, 2, 2.—Subst.: Cy-dōnītes, ae, m. (sc. oi)=nos), quince-wine (cf. B. fin.), Pall. Oct. 20.—
Cydōnĭātae, ārum, m., the inhabitants of Cydonia, Liv. 37, 60, 3; Plin. 8, 58, 83, § 228.

front_matter: Cȳgnēïus, cȳgnēus, and cȳgnus, v. Cycn-.

entries: in the form of a cylinder, cylindrical: siliquae,Plin. 18, 12, 33, § 125.
a cylinder.
Meton.
A cylindrical stone for levelling the ground, a roller, etc., Cato, R. R. 129; Verg. G. 1, 178; Plin. 19, 8, 46, § 158; Vitr. 10, 6 al.—
A precious stone ground off in the form of a cylinder, Plin. 37, 5, 20, § 78; 37, 8, 34, § 113; Juv. 2, 61 al.
A Centaur, Ov. M. 12, 393 and 408.—
The horse of Pollux, given to him by Juno, Verg. G. 3, 90; Stat. Th. 6, 327; Val. Fl. 1, 426; cf. Mart. 8, 21, 5; 8, 28, 8.

A high mountain in the north-eastern part of Arcadia, on which, acc. to the myth, Mercury was born and brought up; hence, consecrated to him, now Zyria, Plin. 10, 30, 45, § 87; Ov. F. 2, 276; 5, 87; Verg. A. 8, 139. —
Hence,
Cyllēnĭus, a, um, adj., Cyllenian: mons,Mel. 2, 3, 5: proles,i. e. Mercury,Verg. A. 4, 258; in this sense also subst.: Cyllēnĭus, ĭi, m., Verg. A. 4, 252; 4, 276; Ov. M. 1, 713; 2, 720 et saep.—
Of or pertaining to Mercury: proles, i. e. Cephalus, son of Mercury by Creüsa, Ov. A.   A. 3, 725: ignis,the planet Mercury,Verg. G. 1, 337.—
Cyllēnēus, a, um, adj., Cyllenian: vertex,Ov. M. 11, 304: fides, i. e. lyra,Hor. Epod. 13, 9; as a constellation,Cic. Arat. 627.—
Cyllēnis, ĭdis, f.adj., Cyllenian, or of Mercury: harpe,possessed by Mercury,Ov. M. 5, 176: planta,i. e. the foot of Mercury,Sil. 16, 500.—
Cyllē-nĭdes, ae, m., one sprung from Cyllene, of Mercury, Mart. Cap. 9, § 899.—
A town in Elis, Liv. 27, 32, 2; Mel. 2, 3, 9; Plin. 4, 5, 6, § 13.—
A nymph, nurse of Mercury, Paul. ex Fest. p. 52, 5; cf. Serv. ad Verg. A. 4, 252.

pertaining to Cylon, the well-known Athenian: scelus = a)/gos *kulw/neion, the crime committed by the murder of Cylon's partisans at the altar of Athene, where they had sought asylum, Cic. Leg. 2, 11, 28.
a young sprout of a cabbage; neutr., Lucil. ap. Non. p. 195, 5; Col. 10, 129; fem., id. 11, 3, 24; 12, 54, 3; Plin. 19, 8, 41, § 137 sq.; 20, 9, 35, § 90 al.—
A hollow sphere, spherical layer, stratum: quarum (naturarum) circa ... centron, aquae primum, aërisque sequens, tertium ignis cyma commemorant,Mart. Cap. 8, § 814 Kopp ad loc.; cf. the context.
front_matter: cȳma (cūma), ătis, n., and ae, f., = ku=ma,
Cȳmaeus, a, um, v. 1. Cyme, II.

entries: The volute of an Ionic column, Vitr. 3, 5, 7; 4, 1, 7.—
A channel, a waved moulding, an ogee, Vitr. 3, 5, 10; 4, 3, 6; 4, 3, 8; 4, 6, 2; Tert. Idol. 8.
front_matter: cȳmătĭum (cūm-) or -on, ii, n., = kuma/tion (a small wave); in architecture,

entries: a boat, skiff, first used by the Phoenicians, Plin. 7, 55, 57, § 208; Afran. in Non. p. 535, 31; Cic. Off. 3, 14, 59; Ov. M. 1, 293; id. F. 6, 777 al.—In partic., the boat of Charon which transported the dead, Verg. A. 6, 303; Hor. C. 2, 3, 28; Prop. 3 (4), 18, 24; Stat. S. 2, 1, 186.—
Trop.: non est ingenii cymba gravanda tui,i. e. meddle not with themes above your powers,Prop. 3, 3 (4, 2), 22; cf. Ov. A. A. 3, 26; Quint. 12, 10, 37.
a plant, also called cotyledon, App. Herb. 43.
pertaining to a cymbal: voces, Ven. Carm. 2, 10 fin.
to strike the cymbals, Cass. Hem. ap. Non. p. 90, 25.
a cymbal-player, App. de Deo Socr. p. 49, 18.
a female cymbal-player, Petr. 22 fin.; Inscr. Orell. 2449 sq.

front_matter: cymbălītis, is, f., = kumbali=tis, sc. herba, = cymbalaris, Marc. Emp. 14.

entries: gen. plur. cymbalum, Cat. 63, 21), = ku/mbalon, a cymbal.

Prop., an instrument consisting of two hollow plates of brass, which emit a ringing sound when struck together. They were used in the festivals of Cybele and Bacchus, and on other festive occasions; also to hinder the flight of bees, etc. (usu. in plur.), Lucr. 2, 619; Cat. 63, 21; 63, 29; Ov. F. 4, 213; Verg. G. 4, 64; Liv. 39, 8; Cic. Pis. 9, 20 sq.; Plin. 5, 1, 1, § 7; Quint. 11, 3, 59; Plin. Ep. 2, 14, 13.—
Transf., in hydraulics, a sounding basin of similar form, a bell, Vitr. 10, 8, 5.—

Trop.: Apion Grammaticus, hic quem Tiberius Caesar cymbalum mundi vocabat, i. e. as making the world ring with his ostentatious disputations, Plin. H. N. praef. § 25; cf. Verg. Cat. 7, 5 Wagn.; App. Orth. § 8 p. 129 Mai.
a small drinking-vessel, a cup, bowl, Varr. ap. Non. p. 545, 28; Verg. A. 3, 66; 5, 267; Mart. 8, 6, 2; cf. Macr. S. 5, 21; Paul. ex Fest. p. 51, 10 Müll.—
A lamp in the same form, App. M. 11, p. 261. 40.
a small boat, Plin. Ep. 8, 20, 7.
a town of Aeolis, near the mod. Sanderli or Sandarlio, Mel. 1, 18, 1; Plin. 5, 30, 32, § 121; Nep. Alcib. 7, 1; Liv. 37, 11, 15; Vell. 1, 4, 4; Tac. A. 2, 47.—
Hence, Cȳmaeus, a, um,  adj., of Cyme: Athenagoras,Cic. Fl. 7, 17: fundus,id. ib. 20, 46: Antigonus,Varr. R. R. 1, 1, 8; Col. 1, 1, 9.—In plur.: Cȳmaei, ōrum, m., inhabitants of Cyme, Liv. 38, 39, 8.
a town in Thessaly, Liv. 32, 13, 10.
a Nereid, Verg. A. 5, 826; 10, 225; Hyg. Fab. praef.
front_matter: Cȳmŏdŏcē, ēs, or Cȳmŏdŏcēa, ae, f.,

entries: full of shoots: stirps,Col. 10, 138.
A Nereid, Verg. A. 1, 144; Prop. 2 (3), 26, 16; Sil. 3, 58 al.—
A fountain in Achaia, Plin. 4, 5, 6, § 13.
a tender sprout: coriandri,Plin. Val. 1, 44.
a tree in Arabia that produced cotton: Bombax ceiba, Linn.; Plin. 12, 11, 22, § 39.
dog-thorn, dog-rose; perh. Rosa canina, Linn.; Plin. 11, 35, 41, § 118.
an Athenian, famous for his valor in the battle of Marathon, Just. 2, 9, 16; Suet. Caes. 68.
a wild tribe of Ethiopia, Plin. 6, 30, 35, § 195.
an inflammation of the throat, which caused the tongue to be thrust out, Cael. Aur. Acut. 3, 1, 3.
a river which empties into the Euxine, Ov. P. 4, 10, 49.
Cynegetics, the name given to poems on hunting by Gratius Faliscus and Nemesianus in Latin, and by Oppianus in Greek.
front_matter: Cynēgĕtĭca, ōrum, n. ( = ta\ kunhgetika/, from kunhgetiko/s, venaticus, pertaining to the chase),

entries: mare,the Hellespont,Hyg. Fab. 111; 243.
the Cynic sect, Aus. Epigr. 27.

Subst., a Cynic philosopher, a Cynic, Cic. de Or. 3, 17, 62; id. Fin. 3, 20, 68; Hor. Ep. 1, 17, 18; Juv. 13, 121: nudi dolia,i. e. of Diogenes,id. 14, 309.—Hence, adj.: Cynĭcus, a, um, Cynic: institutio,Tac. A. 16, 34: cena,Petr. 14; and in * adv.: Cynĭcē, after the manner of the Cynics, Plaut. Stich. 5, 4, 22.—
Suffering byspasmo\s kuniko/s, spasmodic distortion, Plin. 25, 5, 24, § 60; cf. Cels. 4, 2, 2.
a kind of lettuce, Veg. Art. Vet. 3, 4, 29.
Cynical philosophy or conduct, Cassiod. Hist. Eccl. 7, 2.
a kind of nasturtium, App. Herb. 20.
the heat of the dog-days, Plin. Val. 3, 14.
dog's-head, a magical plant, called also osiritis, Plin. 30, 2, 6, § 18.
front_matter: cynŏcĕphălēa (-līa), ae, f. (cynŏ-cĕphălĭon, ii, n., App. Herb. 87), = kunokefa/laion,

entries: An ape with a dog's head (in Africa): Simia inuus, Linn.; Plin. 6, 30, 35, § 190; 8, 54, 80, § 216; 37, 9, 40, § 124; Cic. Att. 6, 1, 25.—
The dog-headed Anubis, Tert. Apol. 6.—
A kind of wild man, Isid. Orig. 11, 3, 15; 12, 2, 32.
adj., having pairs of projecting teeth, Isid. Orig. 11, 3, 7 al.
hound's-tongue, a plant.
Cynoglossum officinale, Linn.; Plin. 25, 8, 41, § 81.—
Another kind producing small burs, Plin. 25, 8, 41, § 81 fin.
another name of the plant psyllion, Plin. 25, 11, 90, § 140.
dog - bread, a plant, App. Herb. 109.
aplant, broom-rape, also called orobanche, Plin. 22, 25, 80, § 162.
the herb fleabane, Plin. 25, 11, 90, § 140.
men with dogs' heads, Tert. Apol. 8.
a plant, dog's-eye, Plin. 21, 17, 61, § 101.
The dog-rose: Rosa canina, Linn. Form -oda,Plin. 8, 41, 63, § 152; 24, 13, 74, § 121.—Form -odon, Plin. 29, 4, 30, § 94; 25, 2, 6, §§ 17 and 18 al. —
The blossom of the red lily: cynorrodon,Plin. 21, 5, 11, § 24.
front_matter: cynorrŏdon (-rhŏd-), i, n., and -da, ae, f., = kuno/rrodon.

entries: a harbor of Locris, at the northern end of the Opuntian bay, Liv. 28, 6, 12; Mel. 2, 3, 4.
a gymnasium near Athens sacred to Hercules, Liv. 31, 24, 18.
The dog-rose or wild-brier, Plin. 16, 37, 71, § 179; Col. 11, 3, 4; App. Herb. 87.—
Cynosbatos, also called cynapanxis or neurospastos, the black currant: Ribes nigrum, Linn.; Plin. 24, 14, 74, § 121; also called cynospastos (kuno/spastos), id. ib.—
The caper - bush: Capparis spinosa, Linn.; Plin. 13, 23, 44, § 127.
name of two hills near Scotussa in Thessaly, Liv. 33, 7, 3; 33, 16, 1; 36, 8, 3.
a sea-polypus, Plin. 32, 11, 53, § 147.
front_matter: cynos dexia, ae, f., = kuno\s decia/,

entries: hound's-cod, a plant, Plin. 27, 8, 42, § 65.
fin.
a promontory of the Thracian Chersonese where Hecuba was buried, Plin. 4, 11, 18, § 49; Mel. 2, 2, 7; Sol. 10, 22; Mart. Cap. 6, § 658; cf. Ov. M. 13, 570.
The constellation at the north pole, the Cynosura, or Lesser Bear, Cic. Ac. 2, 20, 66; id. poët. N. D. 2, 41, 105 and 106; Caes. Germ. Arat. 187; Ov. F. 3, 107 al.—Hence,
Cynŏsūris, ĭdis, f.adj., of or pertaining to the Cynosura: Ursa,the Lesser Bear,Ov. Tr. 5, 3, 7: cauda,Caes. Germ. Arat. 189.—
A town in Arcadia, Stat. Th. 4, 295.
addle-eggs, Plin. 10, 60, 80, § 167 (id. 10, 58, 79, § 160, called also hypenemia or zephyria ova, wind-eggs, in pure Lat. urina ova).
a promontory in Attica, west of Marathon, now Schoinia, or Cap Cabala, Cic. N. D. 3, 22, 57; Lact. 1, 10, 12.
a plant, called also chamaeleon and ulophonon, prob. Chamaeleon niger, Linn.; Plin. 22, 18, 21, § 47.
a mountain of Delos, celebrated as the birthplace of Apollo and Diana, now Montecintio, Plin. 4, 12, 22, § 66; Ov. M. 2, 221; 6, 204 al.— Hence,
Cynthĭus, a, um, adj., of or pertaining to Cynthus, Cynthian: mons,Plin. 4, 12, 22, § 66 Sillig.—As subst.,
Cynthĭus, ii, m., the Cynthian god, i. e. Apollo, Prop. 2 (3), 34, 80; Hor. C. 1, 21, 2; Ov. F. 3, 346 al.—
Cynthĭa, ae, f., the Cynthian goddess, i. e. Diana, Hor. C. 3, 28, 12; Ov. M. 2, 465; 7, 755; id. F. 2, 91 al.—
Also for Luna, the moon, as a goddess, Sen. Herc. Oet. 641; Luc. 1, 218.—
The name of a maiden, Prop. 2 (3), 29, 24.sq.; Ov. R. Am. 764 al.
a town in Messenia, now Arkadhia, Plin. 4, 5, 7, § 15; Liv. 32, 21; called also Cypărissae, ārum, Mel. 2, 3, 9.—Hence,
Cypărissĭus, a, um, adj., of or pertaining to Cyparissa: sinus, Gulf of Arkadhia, Plin. l. l.; Mel. l. l.
a kind of fiery meteors, Sen. Q. N. 1, 15, 4; Paul. ex Fest. p. 51, 13 Müll. (Cyparissae, id. ib. p. 64, 2).
a species of tithymalus, Plin. 26, 8, 43, § 70.
cypress-bearing: Lycaeus,Sid. Carm. 23, 417.

front_matter: Cypărissĭus, a, um, v. Cyparissa, II.

entries: a plant, App. Herb. 3.

front_matter: cypărissus and Cypărissus, i, v. cupressus.

entries: the mistress of the poet Ovid, Ov. Am. 2, 7, 17 sq.
the root of the plant cyperos, Plin. 21, 18, 70, § 117.
a kind of rush, Plin. 21, 18, 70, §§ 117 and 118.
front_matter: cypērŏs, i, m. (cypērum, i, n., Varr. R. R. 3, 16, 13), = ku/peiros,

entries: an Egyptian perfuming powder, Scrib. Comp. 70; Hier. in Jovin. 2, 8.
a plant, pure Lat. gladiolus, Plin. 21, 17, 67, § 107; 21, 18, 69, § 115.—A kindr. species is called cypīra, ae, f., Plin. 21, 18, 70, § 117.

front_matter: Cȳprĭăcus, a, um, v. Cyprus, II. C.

entries: Cyprian, a celebrated Church father of the third century, bishop at Carthage, Lact. 5, 1, 24; Hier. Ep. 58, n. 10; Sulp. Sev. Dial. 1, 3.
a prefect of Cyprus, Vulg. Macc. 2, 12, 2.

front_matter: Cȳprĭcus, a, um, v. Cyprus, II. B.

entries: a fragrant oil, made from the blossoms of the cyprus (ku/pros), cyprus-oil, cyprus-ointment, Plin. 15, 7, 7, § 28; 13, 1, 2, § 5 sq.; 28, 8, 28, § 109; Cels. 2, 33; 4, 20 al.
a species of carp, Plin. 9, 51, 74, § 162; 9, 16, 25, § 58.

front_matter: Cȳpris, ĭdis, v. Cyprus, II. D.

entries: a street in Rome: a cypro, quod ibi Sabini cives additi consederunt, qui a bono omine id appellarunt; nam cyprum Sabine bonum,Varr. L. L. 5, § 159 Müll.; cf. Liv. 1, 48, 6.

front_matter: Cȳprĭus, a, um, v. Cyprus, II. A.

entries: an island in the Mediterranean Sea, on the coast of Asia Minor, renowned for its fruitfulness, its rich mines, especially of copper, and for the worship of Venus, Mel. 2, 7, 5; Plin. 5, 31, 35, § 129; Cic. Att. 9, 9, 2; id. Fam. 15, 4, 15; Hor. C. 1, 3, 1; 1, 19, 10; Ov. M. 10, 270 et saep. —
Hence,

Cȳprĭus, a, um, adj., Cyprian: merces,Hor. C. 3, 29, 60: trabs,id. ib. 1, 1, 13: tellus,i. e. Cyprus,Ov. M. 10, 645: laurus,Plin. 15, 30, 39, § 127 et saep.— But esp. freq. Cyprium aes, also absol.: Cȳprĭum, ii, n. (late Lat. cuprum, Spart. Carac. 9, hence), Engl. copper, Plin. 34, 8, 20, § 94; Isid. Orig. 16, 20, 2.—Hence,

Cȳ-prĭus, a, um, adj., of copper, copper-: in mortariis,Plin. 33, 5, 29, § 93: vas,id. 23, 3, 37, § 74 Jan. and Sillig (al. cypreo): in pyxide,id. 28, 8, 27, § 95; cf.: pyxide aeris Cyprii,Scrib. Comp. 37: pes Cyprios, in versification, ˘¯˘˘¯,Diom. 3, p. 479.—
Prov.: Cyprio bovi merendam Ennius sotadico versu cum dixit significavit id quod solet fieri in insulā Cypro, in quā boves humano stercore pascuntur, Paul. ex Fest. p. 59, 4 Müll.—
Subst.
Cȳprĭa, ae, f., the Cyprian, i. e. Venus, Tib. 3, 3, 34; cf. Paul. ex Fest. p. 52, 6 Müll.—
In plur.: Cȳprii, ōrum, m., the Cyprians, Plin. 7, 56, 57, § 208; Curt. 4, 3, 11.—
Cȳprĭ-cus, a, um, adj., Cyprian: laurus,Cato, R. R. 8, 2.—
Cȳprĭăcus, a, um, adj., the same: expeditio,Val. Max. 4, 3, n. 2: tauri,Capitol. Gord. 3 fin.—
Cȳpris, ĭdis, f., the Cyprian, i. e. Venus (in post-class. poetry), Aus. Epigr. 57; 106 al.

a tree growing in Cyprus and Egypt; the flower of which yielded the cyprinum: Lawsonia alba, Linn.; Plin. 12, 24, 51, § 109; 23, 4, 46, § 90.
††
cȳprus, a Sabine word, = bonus, v. 1. Cyprius.
front_matter: cȳprus or cȳprŏs, i, f., = ku/pros,

entries: a town in Thrace, on the Hebrus, now Ipsala, Plin. 4, 11, 18, § 43; Liv. 31, 16; 38, 40.—Also Cypsĕla, ae, f., Mel. 2, 2, 6.
a kind of swallow, Plin. 10, 39, 55, § 114.
a tyrant at Corinth, Cic. Tusc. 5, 37, 109.—Hence,
Cypsĕlĭdes, ae, m., = *kuyeli/dhs, the descendant of Cypselus, i. e. Periander, Verg. Cir. 463.

front_matter: Cȳra or Cyrrha, ae, f., = Cyrenae, Ov. lb. 537.

entries: a mountain in Africa, Just. 13, 7.

the chief town of a province of the same name in Libya, now Kuren, celebrated for its trade, and as the birthplace of Callimachus, Eratosthenes, and Aristippus, Mel. 1, 8, 2; Plin. 5, 5, 5, § 31; Sall. J. 19, 3; Plaut. Rud. prol. 41; Cic. Planc. 5, 13; Nep. Ages. 8, 6; Sil. 8, 57; Cat. 7, 4; Sol. 27, 44.—
Hence,

Cȳrēnăĭcus, a, um, adj., Cyrenaic: provincia, or absol.: Cȳrē-năĭca, ae, f., the province Cyrenaica, in Libya, Mel. 1, 8, 1; Plin. 5, 5, 5, § 31 sq.; also Cyrenaica Africa,id. ib. § 8: lacrima, i. e. laser,Scrib. Comp. 167; cf. Plin. 19, 3, 15, § 38 sq.: philosophia,the school of philosophy founded by Aristippus,Cic. de Or. 3, 17, 62.—Subst.: Cȳrēnăĭci, ōrum, m., its adherents, Cic. Ac. 2, 42, 131; id. Tusc. 3, 13, 28; id. Off. 3, 33, 116 al.—
Cȳrē-naeus, a, um, adj., of Cyrene: urbs,i. e. Cyrene,Sil. 8, 159: aquae,i. e. drunk by Callimachus,Prop. 4 (5), 6, 4.—
Subst.: Cȳ-rēnaei, ōrum, m.
The inhabitants of Cyrene, Nep. Hann. 8, 1.—
The adherents of the Cyrenaic philosophy (cf. the preced.), Cic. Ac. 2, 24, 76.—

Cȳrēnensis, e, adj., the same: senatus,Plaut. Rud. 3, 4, 8: populares,id. ib. 3, 2, 1: agri,Cic. Agr. 2, 19, 51: provincia,Dig. 19, 2, 61.—In plur. subst.: Cȳrēnenses, ĭum, m., inhabitants of Cyrene, Sall. J. 79, 2; Plin. 7, 56, 67, § 208; Tac. A. 3, 70.
front_matter: Cȳrēnē, ēs, and Cȳrēnae, ārum, f.,

entries: A nymph, mother of Aristaeus, Verg. G. 4, 376; 4, 354; Just. 13, 7.—
A nymph, mother of Idmon, Hyg. Fab. 14.—
A fountain in Thessaly, Serv. ad Verg. G. 4, 354.
a town of Thessaly, Liv. 31, 41, 5; 36, 10, 5.
the island Corsica, Plin. 3, 6, 12, § 80.—Hence,
Cyrnēus, a, um, adj., Cyrneian or Corsican: taxi,Verg. E. 9, 30: tellus, Sen. l. l.
a town in Sogdiana, Curt. 7, 6, 16.
a province of Syria, called after its town Cyrrhus, Plin. 5, 23, 19, § 81; Cic. Att. 5, 18, 1; 5, 21, 2.
a town in Syria, Plin. 5, 23, 19, § 81; Tac. A. 2, 57.
an Athenian, Cic. Off. 3, 11, 48.
a Median tribe, celebrated as slingers, Liv. 37, 40, 9; 42, 58, 13.
The founder of the Persian monarchy, Cic. Leg. 2, 22, 56; id. Brut. 29, 112; id. Div. 1, 23, 46; Hor. C. 2, 2, 17; 3, 29, 27; called Cyrus Major,Lact. 4, 5, 7.—
Cyrus Minor, a brother of Artaxerxes Mnemon, killed in the battle at Cunaxa, Cic. Div. 1, 25, 52; id. Sen. 17, 59; Nep. Alcib. 9, 5.—
An architect of the time of Cicero, Cic. Q. Fr. 2, 2, 2; id. Att. 2, 3, 2; id. Mil. 17, 46.—Hence,
Cȳrēa, ōrum, n., the structures raised by him, Cic. Att. 4, 10, 2.—
The name of a youth, Hor. C. 1. 33, 6; 1, 17, 25.—
A river of Albania, Plin. 6, 9, 10, § 26 sq.; Mel. 3, 5, 6.
a town and harbor in Ionia, Liv. 36, 43, 10 and 13.
the female pudenda, Aus. Epigr. 123, 5.
a town in Colchis, the birthplace of Medea, Plin. 4, 12, 26, § 86.—
Hence,
Cytaeaeus, a, um, adj., Cytaean;poet. for Medean, i. e. magical: carmina,Prop. 1, 1, 24.—
Cy-taeus, a, um, adj., Cytaean;poet. for Colchian: terrae,i. e. Colchis,Val. Fl. 6, 693: proceres,the Colchians,id. 6, 595; and absol.: Cytaei, ōrum, m., the same, Val. Fl.  6, 428.—
Cytaeis, ĭdis, f., the Cytaean woman, i. e. Medea: nocturna,Prop. 2, 4, 7 (17).

an island in the Aegean Sea, south-west of the promontory Malea, celebrated for the worship of Venus, now Cerigo, Mel. 2, 7, 10; Plin. 4, 12, 19, § 56; Verg. A. 1, 680; Ov. F. 4, 286; id. Am. 2, 17, 4 et saep.—
Hence,
Cy-thĕrēus, a, um, adj., of Cythera, Cytherean: Venus,Hor. C. 1, 4, 5; and far more freq. as subst.,
Cythĕrēa, ae, f., Venus, Prop. 2 (3), 14, 25; Hor. C. 3, 12, 4; Ov. M. 10, 717; id. F. 4, 673; Verg. A. 1, 257.—
Poet. collat. form: Cythērē, ēs, f., Venus: nec bis cincta Diana placet, nec nuda Cythere,Aus. Epigr. 39, 5; Mart. Cap. poët. 9, § 915.—

Cythĕrēĭus, a, um, adj., the same: litora,Ov. M. 10, 529: mensis, i. e. April, consecrated to Venus, id. F. 4, 195: heros,i. e. Aeneas,id. ib. 3, 611; id. M. 13, 625; 14, 584: ales,i. e. a dove,Sil. 3, 683: ignis,i. e. the planet Venus,id. 12, 247: proles,i. e. Hermione,Stat. Th. 4, 554.—
Subst.: Cythĕrēĭa, ae, f., i. e. Venus, Ov. M. 4, 190; 10, 529 al.—
Cythērĭă-cus, a, um, adj., of Cythera: aquae,Ov. H. 7, 60: nectar,Mart. 14, 207: myrtus consecrated to Venus,Ov. F. 4, 15; so, columbae, Nero poët. ap. Sen. Q. N. 1, 5, 6.—
Cy-thĕrēïs, ĭdis, f., the Cytherean, for Venus, Ov. M. 4, 288.—
Cythĕrēĭăs, ădis, f.adj., Cytherean;poet. for belonging or consecrated to Venus: columbae,Ov. M. 15, 386.

front_matter: Cythērē, ēs, f., v. Cythera, II. A. 2.

entries: a mistress of Antonius (Cic. Fam. 9, 26, 2; id. Att. 10, 10, 5 al.), who is sarcastically called Cythērĭus, Cic. Att. 15, 22 fin.; Plin. 8, 16, 21, § 55.
one of the Cyclades, now Thermia, Mel. 2, 7, 11; Plin. 4, 12, 22, § 66; Liv. 31, 15, 8; Ov. M. 5, 252; Tac. A. 3, 69; id. H. 2, 8.—Hence,
Cythnius, a, um, adj., of Cythnos, Cythnian: Timanthes Cythnos,Quint. 2, 13, 13.
the calyx of the pomegranate blossom, Plin. 23, 6, 59, § 110.
an island at the entrance of the Arabian Gulf, producing chrysolite; now Perim, Plin. 6, 29, 34, § 170.
an unknown precious stone, Plin. 37, 10, 56, § 154.
son of Phrixus, and founder of Cytorus, Mel. 1, 19, 8; Val. Fl. 5, 463.
a shrubby kind of clover much valued by the ancients, perh. the shrubby snail-clover: Medicago arborea, Linn.; Varr. R. R. 2, 1, 17; Col. 5, 12: Plin. 13, 24, 47, § 130; Verg. E. 1, 79; 2, 64 al.
front_matter: cytĭsus, i, comm. (cytĭsum, i, n., Varr. R. R. 2, 1, 17; 2, 2, 19), = ku/tisos,

entries: a mountain abounding in boxwood, and a town upon it, in Paphlagonia, now Kidros, Mel. 1, 19, 8; Plin. 6, 2, 2, § 5; Cat. 4, 13; Verg. G. 2, 437; Val. Fl. 5, 106 al.—Hence,
Cytōrĭăcus, a, um, adj., of Cytorus, Cytorian: de monte,Ov. M. 6, 132: pecten,i. e. made of boxwood,id. ib. 4, 311.—
Cytōrĭus, a, um, adj., of Cytorus: in jugo,Cat. 4, 11: montes,Plin. 16, 16, 28, § 71.
a king of the Dolones, after whom the town of Cyzicum was named, Val. Fl. 3, 9 sqq.; Mel. 1, 19, 2; Hyg. Fab. 16.
init.

a town celebrated in ancient times, in Mysia, on an island or peninsula of the same name in the Propontis, now Chizico, Atraki, or Balkiz, Mel. 1, 19, 2; Plin. 5, 32, 40, § 142; Flor. 3, 5, 15; Sall. H. 3, 16 sqq.; and 4, 61, 14 Dietsch.—Hence,

Cȳzĭcēnus, a, um (cf. upon the formation of the word Varr. L. L. 8, § 81 Müll.), adj., of or belonging to Cyzicum: triclinia,Vitr. 6, 10: ostrea,Plin. 32, 6, 21, § 62: marmor,id. 5, 32, 44, § 151.—In plur.: Cȳzĭ-cēni, ōrum, m., the inhabitants of Cyzicum. Cic. Imp. Pomp. 8, 20; Tac. A. 4, 36 al.
front_matter: Cȳzĭcum, i, n. (access. form analog. to the Gr. Cȳzĭcus, i, f., Prop. 3 or 4, 22, 1; and Cȳzĭcŏs, Ov. Tr. 1, 10, 29; Auct. Priap. 76, 13), = *ku/zikos,
